question.text: Light energy is converted into chemical energy during the light-dependent phase and chemical energy is used to

options.text: help in the photolysis of water

produce ATP and  <math><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>
reduce carbon dioxide to carbohydrate during the light-independent phase

both <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow></mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>

solution.text: In light-dependent reactions, solar energy is utilized with the help of chlorophyll in plants and converted to chemical energy in the form of NADPH and ATP which are electron carrier molecules. This chemical energy produced during the light-dependent phase is then used to reduce the water and carbon dioxide to glucose in the light-independent phase.
